*the entry pay is slightly about the minimum wage, with time it will just allow you to survive in Dublin but still very unfair in comparison to the effort.

review_title: Bad environment and being fired for anything
job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Las Vegas, NV
pros:
Nice coworkers and a constant supply of work.

Sometimes water is given.

Very easy to get in as there is no interview.
cons:
*Observations in Las Vegas Warehouse*

Every new hire is very disposable. First day on the job, get heat exhaustion, and vomit while working? Threatened with termination for being a safety hazard. Plus hostility from managers who make it seem as if it is your fault.

Told that if you don't have proper foot wear, it is okay, until the next manager comes by, and fires you during orientation. 

Given a series of questions to memorize. You are fired on the spot if you fail to register a single question or paraphrase.

A minute late? Sent home and possibly fired. Definitely fired on the next one.

One day to call off during a 90 day period. Used it to cover a emergency or because you caught the flu, not wishing to spread it, and want to recover? Fired on the next one.

9 months to get benefits and can't be accelerated due to promotion.

Managers boast about a 60% turnover rate, the "job requires character."

Heatstroke deaths causes the company to install cameras and not a/c in vehicles. 

A constant environment that is above 110° with fans that transfer that heat to you. It is a safety hazard when you can't get a break to get water and it decreases performance.

A break, maybe once every three hours constant work. 

No HR and very possibly a weak Union. 

During one orientation, a group of 15 potential employees were told that they were no call no shows when their orientation was cancelled by management.

Aside from hostility and a firing bananza, besides the hiring managers, most managers/supervisors are apathetic.

Due to the turnover, new employees are thrown at the work with incomplete training as ones who worked there before, leave, or are fired.

Constant malfunctions with the conveyor belt system. Every other minute, the packages you have to sort may be broken apart, or there is a jam, or the conveyor belt does not work at all. 

Not enough scanners to give to those who need it for their job functions. 

Pay is insufficient for the work involved and just a state over, the pay is higher by $5 a hour for the same role in the same company in a smaller, less expensive town.

Bathrooms aren't adequately stocked. Plain water may be the only option to wash your hands.

Nothing, aside from the occasional water bottle, or if you do get a break to fill the one you may have, is given. The boots you need to do the job? Out of pocket. Anything else? Out of pocket. 

You are not allowed to go to your vehicle on your break. You must remain in a 'designated' break area. Or else, fired

There's more, but this list of cons is already fairly long already.

It is very easy to get in and even easier to get out.

pros: part time job so hours weren;t terrible

Didn't inspire much faith in the companies hiring process. They also lost or just plain old didn't pay employees on time or correctly. No one actually appreciates the hard work hourly employees do at that company as much as they want to appear as they do. Great company, poor management.

review_title: UPS - Poor Pay Practices for Frontline Workers
job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Portland, OR
pros: Unionized (Teamsters), Good medical benefits through Teamsters
cons: Low hourly pay for workers, pay not competitive with the surrounding labor market. Minuscule weekly attendance bonus implemented that incentivizes workers to come to work sick. (Really - during a global pandemic??) Attendance bonus was also implemented after they REDUCED base pay. Overall the UPS corporation is having recorded growth and earnings, thanks to the frontline workers who have worked all the way through the pandemic. Yet those workers are not seeing their wages rise increase along with the success that they are making happen for the company. The exec and “corporate” employees are getting rich on the backs of the frontline workers. It’s shameful. No wonder why they are having an attendance and turnover problem. Time to “share the wealth” UPS!

review_title: Not a good place to work
pros: Coworker and other people around the office were very friendly and supportive. Warehouse leads and associates very nice and a joy to work with.
cons:
The entire management structure. From the get go there was little to no support, communication or clear display of expectations. There's a month of on-boarding material, they don't give you anything useful or meaningful to do until the fifth week, they don't include you in meetings so you can learn more and get exposure to the work that is required. Then after only 3 weeks of working on an actual project, get slapped with a performance review so awful that it's basically saying you're finished. After you try everything possible to set up a plan to meet their ever-changing expectations and deadlines, work your butt off and go above and beyond them, they still let you go. This place is an absolute joke. Supervisor is afraid of confrontation, always made his boss do the tough conversations. Would beat around the bush about expectations and shortfalls.
There is no sexual harassment in the workplace or diversity chapters in the on-boarding material. It's all about compliance. This place doesn't care the mental and physical health of its employees.

To add theres no training. Most trainers throw you in a job and expect you to figure it out. During the summer trucks can get up to 120+ degrees f and management expects you to load the same output and dont even bother to give you water at times. I can add more but its a loooong list of just straight nono's

job_title: Package Handler in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: Juggled ups and autzone at once.. latest we get off at autozone is 9:30pm. By 11:00pm I went to ups for 4 hours and by 4:15 I was in the shower and by 4:30 in bed after ironing my autozone uniform.. by 7:30am I was up again to say bye for my oldest to go to school . Then i would Sleep until it was time for me to work so by 2:30pm I was up welcoming my oldest back from school then i would get ready . Put gas if i had to then off to work . Thanks to the Lord i was blessed enough that My fiance would watch my 3 daughters while I was at ups. And she would take my oldest to school and pick her up or Sometimes my mom would if my fiance had a Meeting.. other than regularly having BABYSITTER ISSUES everything worked out perfectly Enough for a 22 year old to work 2 jobs while sleeping 6 hours.. for a couple months for 1 month before, thru, and 1 month after the peak season would end.. also the coworkers I worked with rated 10 out of 10 I enjoyed every part of every conversation with every person I ever had in that building it's a shame that I had to bounce from there but sometimes you got to do what's best for you.
cons:
NO RAISES FOR HARD TO FIND LOYAL HARD-WORKING EMPLOYEES.
They started me out at 16 dollars an hour and one day all the sudden without notice I have grabbed my check like usual on that Friday went to my car and when I opened it to my surprise my check was cut probably about 150 to what it usually is and my pay was $15 now I wanted to go back inside because that night I had worked so hard showed up early and half of the people there had called in and which was not a surprise either and for me to go to my car and my check to be that much shorter like really I felt like if anybody deserves a raise in that hole section were PD 1 2 and 3 where at it was me and a couple others I didn't say nothing nor did I work less hard because of the fact I still kept a strong hard work ethic for a little bit after that some people at work brought up the no change out loud in front of management complaining bickering saying they're going to quit find new jobs and this was days later. Whenever I found out it was that first check cause I check my check everything. A bunch of people that quit because of that fact that they lowered everybody's check that was hired during the peak season. Not saying they were wrong in lowering everyone's pay because it was in the fine print in the application process but that's messed up because there was a few people that we're getting paid 15. 30 while I was getting paid $15 an hour and they put me in high volume constanly and when a manager position comes up they make somebody a manager because of the seniority but to me it's like you need to prove yourself to earn a position like that because every advancement in any job always comes with a raised and me having three daughters I felt like I need a raise it would have been nice I probably would have stayed if it wasn't for the low underpaid part of the job you make less than $1,000 a month with this part time job keep it a part-time job never work at UPS for more than part-time it's not worth it.

pros: I am hard-pressed to find any great reason to work for this company other than compensation and benefits, and at times even that doesn't feel like enough on its own. I will, however, say that the long-term hourly employees were among some of the most hardworking individuals I've ever met in my life and I am forever grateful for the way that they poured into me during my time working alongside them.
cons: My time working at this company has left me scarred and as I hear others share their experiences, I'm more confident in saying my experience was not unique. From day one, I was made to feel expendable and like another name on the payroll. As time went on, I began to notice how the grueling work began to affect me physically (to this day I experience chronic pain), my sleeping patterns were significantly affected, and my mental health took a nosedive. Not to mention, the management made matters worse by adding undue pressure on us to perform and work under duress in extreme conditions.

review_title: Really Enjoyable, Just Keep Perspective (It's Only Seasonal)
job_title: Seasonal PVD Personal Vehicle Driver in Wilmington, NC
pros:
Freedom and being trusted by leadership to complete your job. The experience and pay were awesome as well. 
The permanent employees and drivers were all welcoming and polite to the pvd crew
cons:
Don't get it twisted, that big weekly paycheck you've been getting for the last month and a half will come to a stop just as fast as it started. 
Communication and at what time exactly did I need to report to work wasn't carried out well on a consistent basis. Some pvd's and people in general are ok with that "relaxed" type of expectations but I personally like and need a set time to show and a clear understanding of what is exactly expected. How can anyone fairly assess the performance of someone if they don't know what's expected in detail. 
Lastly, after completing your Christmas Eve route go ahead and do your other gigs or take another job offer from somewhere immediately because for most, your cushy pvd job is a wrap! It's over!

pros: Pay during the holiday season is pretty good and I believe the health insurance is quite good although I haven't gotten it yet, takes 9 months.
cons:
I have no problem working hard, but the management makes the job almost unbearably more difficult for reasons I sometimes can't even wrap my head around.

There are rules you must know in case someone important is around, but most of the time you must learn a new set of rules that apply to day to day. For instance, walking on a moving conveyor belt is "against the rules" however on the day to day everyone does and you are more or less expected to. Just don't fall over or the company now has a legal out because they officially told you not to. 

My supervisor would constantly lie to me about procedures in order to increase productivity at the cost of safety/actual company policy. My Supervisor lied to me about a promotion so that I would stay working there after the holiday season pay raise fell off. Lied to me about when I would get health insurance. Lied to me about covid policy and tried to get me to come in to work despite a positive test and symptoms. I have had to call my union on my supervisor multiple times and every time they are shocked at what this person does next. I was then retaliated against for calling the union but they are your best friend at a place like this so don't be afraid to call. I know not every supervisor will be like this and I probably had the worst of the bunch but still.

pros: Exercise, exercise, exercise, exercise, exercise
cons:
No Communication from upper management or Local Teamster Union 663

Cut Pay-- In Oct of 2021 we opened our paychecks to learn we had recieved a pay increase or some of us did. The comapny was having trouble hiring people at $14 per hour going into our busiest time of the year, so they started to hire new preloaders at $19.5. Any current preloader making less than $19.5 per hour was bumped up to that level. Any current preloader making more than $19.5 was not given the increase. When management was asked about this increase we were told why we recieved and that it was permanent...... Great right? Fast forward to Jan 15, 2022 and when we opened our checks we learned that our pay was reduced to our previous wage prior to the increase. No warning, no communication, no heads from upper management nor from our local Union 633. 20% decrease without warning during a period of the highest inflation in 40yrs. Cruel and absolutely irresponsible!

When grievances are made to Union management will most times retaliate within our Facility

review_title: Great driver pay but grueling work
pros: Pay, Overtime. Teamsters. Health insurance.
cons: Time to become full time can be years with no ability to transfer locations (as a union member). Grueling heat and 12+ hrs worth of work 6 days a week.

pros: The barrier to entry is next-to-none. I applied, submitted my employment documents and scheduled my first day of work in less than an hour. The company makes an effort to develop their employees and prepare them for the work they'll do. Week 1 was classroom group training, week 2 was training on the floor. By week 3, we were cut loose. You will have to maintain good physical fitness and nutrition habits, as the job is very physically demanding. Occasionally you will be told to work in areas where more workers are needed, so you will have to change your work style for different supervisors. The job is unionized, so if you need help, union stewards are available to represent you. With UPS being a promote-from-within company, this job can be a stepping stone to skilled jobs, such as driving, when you gain enough seniority. This is my first "real" job after doing only gig work. It's also a good job if you are a student. Or, if you are trying to get your life back on track after getting laid off elsewhere, or have a criminal history. Second chances are something you can't put a price on.
cons: The pay is as expected: minimum wage, which can increase when contracts are negotiated, though some co-workers of mine with a few years at the company have only had their pay raised by a couple of cents. There are plenty of other jobs you can do for minimum wage without union dues, so come here if you want a union or like the company, otherwise you can make more flipping burgers. As previously mentioned, if you want to move up to other jobs, the wait can vary. Some people move up after a few weeks, while some have to wait for years. It is all seniority-based, so your qualifications really don't matter. It is also easy to get injured at this job, particularly when the workload is heavy and you're being rushed. It can feel endless and overwhelming. You will be moving bulk, working in tight areas, lifting a lot, and most likely working with failing equipment. Your work doesn't end when the clock strikes end time, it ends when the belts are empty and. Some nights you will get held way over. Others, the load will be light, and you can get sent home after 20 minutes if you don't have guaranteed hours. If you accept the risks and wish to proceed, then good luck.

review_title: Hard Labor, Great Health Insurance, A lot of Internal Mobility
pros:
- No background check or drug test. If you've made mistakes in the past or self medicate to get through the struggle that is life, they will still hire you and you are still eligible for all positions in the building. 
- Full range of benefits available to part time employees (most employees are part time)
- Top notch health insurance, I've heard it's even better than what you get as a veteran (like 90% coverage of medical, dental, and vision and your deductible caps at $2000 a year so you can get major surgery / treatment and not have medical debt)
- Internal mobility:  they are always looking to move people up the ladder, especially now with the Atlanta SMART hub still being new, the ranks aren't clogged with sonority. You can come in at the lowest level as a package handler and work your way up to 80 or 100k as a fulltime supervisor, manager, or truck driver. 
- Tuition reimbursement: available immediately after your first 30 days. good for any accredited college or university up to $5250 per year and 25k in total. The HR and Education Team phone lines are responsive as well (in my experience).
cons:
- Hard labor. Most people coming in have to load/unload trucks at one point or another. Especially at the Atlanta S.M.A.R.T Hub, as a new building with high turnover, even the supervisors are loading trucks. It is HARD LABOR. Nothing imposible but you can hurt yourself if you are not careful. 
- health benefits don' t apply until after 9 months so make sure you keep yourself safe that first 9 months. 
- bad management, you'll find this anywhere and  you'll find it here too. Most people try to be cool because they're really in the same boat as you when it comes to this job, but there are always a few who, despite their best effort's, don't know how to manage people or their own frustration.  There is incompetence all the way up the chain and terrible communication to boot. Best way is to not bother thinking critically about something that's not your responsibility.

review_title: Good Benefits, Poor Management Work Ethos
pros:
*Great starting pay.
*Low initial skill requirements for access to most positions.
*Automatic yearly Cost of Living raises.
*Healthcare, once obtained, is quite good.
*Wide array of shift types, and openings for positions are common.
*Part-time overtime pay during peak season adds up early and quickly.
*"Independent" work common.
cons:
*Safety issues are either not quickly rectified by management, or not at all unless it immediately affects the company's bottom line.
*Union contract and corporate chain-of-command rules are often ignored by management, and are needlessly difficult to enforce.
*Training for new employees is mostly "Trial by Fire", with limited tutorialization/practice (assuming anyone is available to train in the first place).
*Weather conditions heavily affect working environment quality, especially heatwaves, excessive rain/floods, or heavy snow.
*Excessively unkempt and dirty work environment both due to other employees and environment type, even with aggressive cleaning.
*Management often ignores suggestions for improvements to work processes.
*Less than a "skeleton crew" worth of employees on-hand regularly due to forced limits from an improperly used analysis system leading to turnover.
*Poor hour count during the off-season.
